actions first of all I'm not going to delve really deeply into what why we

dat tldr when you test the front end of your
website you kind of need a front end you need a live website to go through and
test unlike running run running other tests like unit tests where you can give
it dummy data and that make sure that the output is what you expect it to be for front end tests you need to have a
functioning front end to test against and for front end test like performance
testing it's really important that that is as close to your production environment as
possible for example from this code snippet can anybody tell me if the you
user interface is accessible to anybody using a vision impairment
no can you tell me how long it's going to take for the page to load or if any of the resources are going to block page
loading looking at this CSS code snippet can you determine if any of the code

uh while we can perform some linting and validation against the code that we've written we there's only so much that we
can work out without seeing the final product ideally as I said with a setup as close to production as possible so
that we can make sure that this is actually what's going to happen when we build it out so why GitHub actions I hear you ask
it's a really great question that I want to answer in two parts first of
all while better than manually test while better than nothing manual tests
aren't great because it's hard to ensure that they're being run how many of you enjoy doing repetitive tasks that can be
easily automated if anyone raised their hands I
was going to call them a liar uh none of you it's one of our favorite things to do with AI we can get rid of the
repetitive task that we don't like doing and so when our tests are
automated as any as as part of any kind of process it means that they're

running our tests and when a pipeline is set up properly we can ensure that code
doesn't pass through uh that doesn't pass test and it doesn't accidentally get merged in and we can protect the
quality of our application but why did I choose GitHub
actions for this uh why did I choose GitHub actions for running tests and as a cicd tool uh for the most part it was
the fact that the documentation and the assistance available to me made it really easy uh it meant it wasn't hard
for me to get started it was also compatible with a lot of existing things and tools that I
wanted to be able to use and had great extensibility so works for smaller
projects or bigger Enterprise projects as well while the code and conventions
that I'm going to go through in this session today is specific to GitHub actions the concepts and practices are
ones that you can take and reuse with your own tools and processes for those that aren't familiar
or haven't heard of GitHub actions uh I'm I'm going to assume

if you want to look into it a bit more I would recommend checking out the GitHub documentation and or otherwise flagging
down any of the people from GitHub that are at the conference
today GitHub actions runs what are called workflows which are written
inside workflow files inside a particular folder of your project GitHub
slw workflows as with a lot of devops tools these files are written in yaml
yay we love working with yamore each workflow or action is made
up of one or more jobs uh by default these jobs will all run at the same time
and each job is then made up of one or more steps which will run one after
another so to get started our our workflow file we have a name of our
workflow this is uh people friendly label for us to know which workflow we're running for example here mine is
build and test because we're going to go through and build and test our application next we have a look at how
our workflow is triggered in this case we want our workflow to run every time a
pull request to the production Branch gets opened reopen all the code gets
updated there are many different options of events that can trigger a workflow
these are just a few of the common
ones we can have triggers around creating deleting and updating all sorts
of things on our repository tags Forks issues pull requests you name it it can
probably be integrated with GitHub actions each of these then has more
specific settings for example the pull request trigger allows us to define the different types of events that trigger
the workflow whether all events or just ones that involve the code being changed
uh for example you can just trigger a workflow based on whether or not a PO request is assigned or unassigned uh
whether or not you've got any reviews requested or removed whether or not you've turned on or off auto
merge we can also filter this for specific branches for example this might just be for production Branch for
development Branch or using a wild card for a feature
Branch we can also then filter this down to specific paths for example maybe you
want to run some JavaScript linting or some typescript type check in but only
if specific files like JavaScript or typescript files have been changed we
can be really specific and only run the actions that we need to when we need
them but in this case we want to keep things relatively simple we want to
trigger this when a pull request is submitted in particular when a pull
request is opened reopened or synchronized which means anytime the code in the pool request is
changed we also only want to run this when the pull request is being opened to the production branch of our repos we
don't care about the code that exists on other branches just
yet next in our workflow file we want to go through and Define some jobs the jobs
are specific tasks that the workflow will complete by default these will all run at the same time each job gets a
unique name in this case build but the name must be unique for every workflow
file we then go through and set the platform that the job will run on you
can choose from a number of different options but running on Linux is the
cheapest option and therefore generally the one we're going to end up doing each job then has a number of
steps to complete these will complete one after another uh most of the time your first step is going to be to check
out the code from your REO otherwise you don't really have anything to work
with in terms of the steps the steps are also made up of a name this is optional
and is for us to identify which step is being run we can also give a step a unique
ID uh this is optional and we can use that to refer to the step elsewhere
inside of our workflow we can Define what the step is actually doing in two different ways one
of them is using users this allows us to define a specific package that we're
going to go through and run for example there's a package for setting up node which will set up the version of node
that we're using uh there's a package to check out the repository code and
there's a whole bunch of thirdparty packages that we have access to using as well alternatively we can use run to run
our Command inside of the uh the GitHub actions terminal and we can go through
and run whatever command we like using whatever we've installed in there
some steps we can also add checks to
check whether or not a specific condition is met before we're running them for example we can check if our
workflow has failed we can do a thing so in this case if a workflow has failed we
could add a comment to the pr to go this has failed or send a notification to slack or teams or post on a social media
platform we can do whatever we want with that
each of our steps we can then add some additional information for example we
probably want to add environment variables to some on here we can add environment variables plain text but
most of the time we're probably going to be working with secret values so we can load in some secret values from

property this is specific to a lot of the packages we use for example the setup node package you tell it what
